Comment: The Queen game from my opponent, Blitzkov.
I always do nf3 in a Queen Game.
I can go Nimzo Attack or King's Indian.  It depends upon my mood at the time. Either work.
I felt at this day and time I needed to do the King's Indian Defense.
Usual for the d4 development.
Usual line to prevent losing control over the center of the board.
Expected.
It blocks and attacks (my knight).
Perhaps Blitzkov is a fianchetto person here on his king side.  It takes time to develop a fianchetto.
The King's Indian is designed to use the fianchetto. I was later than earlier to start it.
So he does the fianchetto.
I have pressure on his d4 pawn while making a trade to isolate his "a" rank pawn. Why not?
So now his "a" rank pawn is isolated in a trade. I am happy so far.
With this move I make him trade queens at the outset before he can castle. He should not take my e5 pawn unless he wants to risk a centrally fixed king without shelter.
So he is ahead of my thinking and knows the fault there....

I am playing a 14 year old. And is he smart!  When he came into GK I thought he was just an ego that needed an ego beating. 
So I do get a trade to open up my own fianchetto (the only time, usually, I ever employ the fianchetto is in the King's Indian Defense. It is a solid defense against d4 to date).
He had to go this way. If he had done e3xd4 then his pawns (and pawn skeleton) would be compromised.

I do this to engage but mostly to allow my queen to move about the d8-a5 diagonal. At the same time I am still ready to do QxQ if d4 takes c5. In the latter case White can't really castle. In the former case ????
Another fianchetto move by blitzkov! Well, it is time to put him into check...
He can only do qd2 or just sit back for an onslaught.  By this time I know my 14 year old opponent is going for qd2.
